title: Thomas Keller to Close Hudson Yards Restaurant in New York City
summary: TAK Room is one of the highest-profile restaurant casualties to date from the coronavirus pandemic. Michelin-starred chef Thomas Keller said Wednesday that he is shutting down his TAK Room restaurant at Hudson Yards, one of the highest-profile closings to date due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Where Kamala Harris Calls Home
summary: The California senator and VP nominee owns property in L.A.'s Brentwood neighborhood, as well as San Francisco and Washington, D.C.. A quick Google search for Sen. Kamala Harris's house turns up shots of a three-bedroom house in a quiet enclave near downtown Sacramento, Calif.

title: Biden-Harris Ticket Makes Debut After Historic VP Pick
summary: Harris beat 10 other finalists for No. 2 spot; campaign officials say she displayed knowledge of policy, confidence in challenging Trump. WILMINGTON, Del.-Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made their public debut Wednesday as Democratic running mates and emphasized the historic choice of the senator from California, who beat out 10 other finalists to become the first Black woman and the first woman of Indian ancestry on a major-party presidential ticket.

title: Revlon Lenders Sue Over 'Theft' of $1.8 Billion Loan Collateral
summary: A group of lenders alleged the MacAndrews & Forbes-backed company improperly shifted valuable brand assets out of their reach. Revlon Inc. faces a lawsuit alleging the cosmetics company siphoned off valuable intellectual property that had been pledged to investors, depriving them of the collateral they bargained for.

title: Getting to Know Kamala Harris
summary: How Biden's running mate blocked a hospital rescue to help the SEIU.. Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made their first appearances as a campaign ticket on Wednesday, and Americans still know little about the running mate who may be President sooner rather than later. One way to fill in the gap is to inspect Ms. Harris's record as California's Attorney General, and one revealing episode is the way she used her power to blow up a deal to rescue struggling Catholic hospitals.

title: DeVos's Sexual-Assault Rule Prevails
summary: The new standard for due process on campus survives in court.. One of the stakes in November's election is the fate of the Trump Administration's due-process reforms for campus sexual-assault cases. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos's new rule goes into effect Friday, and this week it passed its first legal tests.

title: Where Is the U.S.-U.K. Trade Deal?
summary: An agreement should be easier to reach than London seems to think.. The third round of negotiations between the United States and the United Kingdom for a new trade deal has come and gone and, well, where is it? President Trump and Prime Minister Boris Johnson each say they're enthusiastic, and both economies could use the boost. Yet a deal is turning out to be harder than expected, and for all the wrong reasons.

title: Florida, Felons and Judicial Bullying
summary: Democratic Senators try to intimidate federal judges into recusing.. The 10 Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee wrote to three federal judges recently, demanding that they "explain" how their conduct in a pending case doesn't break ethics rules. It's another attempt by Democrats to intimidate the judiciary, similar to their threat last year that if the Supreme Court upheld gun rights, it might be "restructured."

title: Lyft's Uphill Climb Faces Potholes
summary: Company says ride-hailing demand has improved, but avoids giving forecast. Lyft swears its business is getting better, but the numbers don't show it yet. Investors would be wise to heed some yellow flags.

title: J.C. Penney Landlords Nearing Deal to Buy Bankrupt Retailer
summary: Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners are nearing a possible deal to purchase the department-store chain's retail operations out of bankruptcy. Two of J.C. Penney Co. 's largest landlords have emerged as the leading contenders to acquire the department-store chain's retail business out of bankruptcy, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Coronavirus Negotiators Remain 'Miles Apart,' Pelosi Says
summary: Standoff between Democrats and GOP over another coronavirus-relief bill shows no signs of abating. WASHINGTON-A dayslong standoff between Democrats and Republicans over another coronavirus-relief bill showed no signs of abating Wednesday, as negotiations threatened to stall until next month, when lawmakers must reach an agreement to keep the federal government funded.

title: Lyft Ridership, Revenue Drop Amid Rising Coronavirus Infections
summary: Ride-hailing company's pandemic woes add to regulatory challenges ahead. Lyft Inc. reported a dramatic drop in riders and revenue in the second quarter, as rising coronavirus infections in the U.S. and prolonged shutdowns weighed on its results.

title: Facebook and Other Tech Giants Gird for Chaotic Election
summary: Social-media platforms talk with federal officials as Trump questions legitimacy of voting by mail. Facebook Inc., Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Twitter Inc. have discussed with federal officials how the social-media platforms can prevent the spread of misinformation in the days before and after the election, after the U.S. intelligence community warned of foreign interference and President Trump called the vote's integrity into question.

title: Verity Gets Green Light to Sell Los Angeles Hospital Out of Bankruptcy
summary: Judge overseeing Verity's bankruptcy approves sale of St. Francis to Prime Healthcare despite objections from California's attorney general. Hospital operator Verity Health System of California Inc. won bankruptcy-court approval to sell a Los Angeles-area facility to Prime Healthcare Services Inc. for more than $350 million despite objections from the state attorney general and an opposing bidder.

title: Fed Officials Warn Pandemic Response Is Hobbling Economic Rebound
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren says states' inability to control the virus will prolong downturn; San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly calls for more stimulus. Federal Reserve officials said a recent slowdown in U.S. economic activity was likely to persist because of difficulties states have encountered in suppressing the coronavirus pandemic, which could require more government spending to support the economy.

title: U.S. Treasury Fines Former Army Employee Over Gifts to Alleged Narcotics Trafficker
summary: Settlement stands as a reminder that the Office of Foreign Assets Control will still pursue cases against individuals. A former employee of the U.S. Army agreed to a settlement with the U.S. Treasury Department to resolve allegations that the employee provided gifts to an individual designated by the U.S. as a narcotics trafficker.

title: Why Kamala Harris Is Known as a 'Running Mate'
summary: The expression jumped to American politics from 19th-century harness races, where a second horse helped pull the load. Former Vice President Joe Biden made the long-awaited announcement of his running mate on Tuesday, after formally asking Sen. Kamala Harris via Zoom call to join him on the Democratic Party's presidential ticket. With Mr. Biden and Ms. Harris now set to square off against President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence, it's a moment to consider our customary terminology for such partnerships. How did "running mate" become the default expression for a vice-presidential candidate?

title: Sumner Redstone Dies at 97; Media Mogul Who Said 'Content Is King'
summary: He built an empire of TV, movies and radio that became focus of power struggle. Sumner Redstone, who turned his family's movie-theater company into a global media empire spanning television, movies, radio and books, and who famously proclaimed that "content is king," has died.

title: Netflix to Stream 'Diana' Musical While Broadway Is Closed
summary: Shows that might never have been on audiences' radars are able to gain global exposure thanks to filmed versions, some theater professionals say. Broadway might be closed until at least January, but another show is finding a home in the streaming world during the interim.

title: Cisco to Pursue Deep Cost Cuts in Corporate Tech-Spending Slowdown
summary: Company to focus more research and development spending on cloud-computing and security. Networking-equipment giant Cisco Systems Inc. said it would adjust investment plans and pursue deep cost cuts as customer priorities have shifted during the coronavirus pandemic, which contributed to the company posting the first annual revenue decline in three years.

title: New York City Principals Union Calls for Schools to Reopen Remotely for Three Weeks
summary: Union says delaying reopening would allow more time to ensure schools have enough nurses and ventilation systems are repaired as precautions against coronavirus. The union that represents New York City's principals on Wednesday officially pressed the mayor to delay reopening schools for in-person instruction until the end of September, saying they need more time and information to safeguard students and teachers against the coronavirus.

title: The Gulf War Ended Too Soon
summary: Bush was right not to go all the way to Baghdad, but he should have backed Shiite rebels in southern Iraq.. Thirty years ago this month, on Aug. 2, 1990, Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. The U.S. mounted an impressive response, but strategic errors at the end of the Gulf War had consequences the world still lives with today.

title: Individual Choice Is a Bad Fit for Covid Safety
summary: Consider the externalities: We each choose whether to isolate or wear a mask, but all society bears the costs.. The U.S. government's disastrous failure in dealing with the coronavirus pandemic is a tragedy in many acts-from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's initial errors with test kits and masking, to a know-nothing president who confuses magical thinking with thinking, even to craven political considerations when the pandemic was seen as a blue-state problem, and much more.

title: Election 2020: The Year of Weird
summary: Conventions are over, and voters may actually care about the vice president.. One of the strangest years in American politics keeps getting stranger. One example is what's happened to the quadrennial national party conventions, which have been an integral part of American politics since 1831, when the parties replaced the old system in which members of Congress selected the nominees.

title: Law Alone Can't Protect Free Speech
summary: If today's cultural trends continue, judges will eventually curtail First Amendment rights.. Cancel culture notwithstanding, legal commentator Ken White argues that "this is a golden age for free speech in America." For decades, he notes, the Supreme Court has protected all manner of objectionable speech, from burning the American flag to homophobic protests outside servicemen's funerals. That's true-but those victories rest on a broad cultural consensus. If campus norms continue to displace free speech culture, judges and lawyers will eventually start to ignore the First Amendment or, worse, chip away at it until it is meaningless.

title: Notable & Quotable: NASA's Celestial Microaggressions
summary: 'Certain cosmic nicknames are not only insensitive, but can be actively harmful.'. From an Aug. 5 National Aeronautics and Space Administration press release:

title: S&P 500 Climbs but Closes Below a Record
summary: Stocks have risen in all but one day in August, boosted by declining coronavirus cases and government stimulus. U.S. stocks climbed Wednesday, extending a steady August rally that has pushed the S&P 500 to the cusp of its first record close since the coronavirus pandemic brought the economy to a halt.

title: 'Leave It as It Is' Review: 'Man Can Only Mar It'
summary: Though a paradoxical ﬁgure, Teddy Roosevelt was undoubtedly a ﬁghter for what he believed in, including the preservation of the natural world.. More than a century after his death, Theodore Roosevelt still inspires with his ferocious energy, consummate intelligence and manifold achievements. But perhaps most fascinating is his complex, even paradoxical, personality. A man with genuine empathy for the disadvantaged, he embraced the racial and cultural prejudices of his time; an avowed trustbuster, he accepted the patronage of banks and corporations; a steadfast conservationist, he slaughtered hundreds of wild animals. Today, when the legacies of many American heroes are being re-examined, what are we to make of Teddy Roosevelt?

title: Black Mothers in New York Are More Likely to Have Life-Threatening Complications in Childbirth
summary: Advocates are calling for policies to reduce disparities in maternal mortality between Black and white women. Last September, Shamony Makeba Gibson was discharged after the birth of her second child and was in pain. It wasn't just the caesarean section. She didn't feel right, wasn't managing daily activities, and in the evenings felt hot and had difficulty breathing.

title: Rival Moguls Hail Sumner Redstone's Drive, 'Business Thuggery'
summary: Barry Diller, John Malone pay tribute to media magnate, who died at 97. Media mogul Sumner Redstone is remembered by his friends, business partners and competitors for his tenacity and relentlessness as he built one of the nation's largest entertainment empires.

title: Original Tipster in College-Admissions Case Gets Year in Prison
summary: Morrie Tobin will serve 12-month sentence for stock fraud after judge awarded 'large and unprecedented discount' for government cooperation. A Los Angeles businessman whose tip led the government to unravel the massive Operation Varsity Blues college-admissions scam was sentenced to 12 months in prison for his role in a separate securities-fraud case.

title: Silicon Valley Sees Kamala Harris as One of Its Own
summary: Joe Biden's VP pick has forged deep ties with tech-industry executives but sometimes stands against their interests. Silicon Valley has a potential ally in its future with Kamala Harris, a California senator who has strong ties to executives behind the nation's technology giants and has been largely silent about the antitrust issues currently plaguing them.

title: Coronavirus's Long, Deadly Plateau in the Developing World
summary: Resume Subscription. The intensive-care units at the Salvador Zubirán hospital in Mexico City have been operating at full capacity for three straight months-their beds filled with unconscious Covid-19 patients, positioned face down and connected to ventilators. Every person who dies or recovers is replaced within hours by another who is critically ill and in need of life support.

title: A Bel-Air Home Office That Will Make You See Red
summary: The owners paid $75,000 to develop a custom color scheme for the room. Coating the walls of a home office in an intense, lacquered shade of red might not be for everyone, but to designer Ernest de la Torre it was one way to bring a punch of energy to an otherwise minimalist Bel-Air home.

title: Regulators Warn NJ Transit at Risk of Missing Safety Deadline
summary: Railroad has until end of the year to install positive-train control; NJT 'fully expects to make it'. Federal regulators warned that NJ Transit is at risk of missing a federally imposed deadline to install a train safety system by the end of the year.

title: Waystar Agrees to Buy eSolutions at $1.3 Billion Valuation
summary: The deal would combine two health-care billing and payment technology providers. Health-care payments business Waystar Inc. has agreed to acquire eSolutions Inc. in a deal that values the revenue cycle management provider at around $1.3 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Daily Coronavirus Case Count Drops to Lowest Level Since Early August
summary: Some college football leagues are postponing seasons as school debate continues. The U.S. reported more than 46,000 new coronavirus cases, its lowest new daily tally since Aug. 3.

title: Abroad at Home: Architectural Clickbait
summary: Setting foot in great buildings might not be an option right now, but you can still take tours of structures like the Sydney Opera House, the Villa Savoye and the Guggenheim Bilbao thanks to digital technology.. If we have learned anything this year, it is that virtual reality is a pitiful substitute for the real thing. Architecture is not only a visual but a spatial medium, which we experience with our entire body, consciously and unconsciously. Even with the finest digital simulation we miss the evidence of our other senses-the resonant echoes that tell us the shape, size and materials of a space; the distinctive fragrance that gives every room an olfactory fingerprint (like the uncanny combination of chalk dust, beeswax and resinous wood in our old schoolrooms). But as it happens, a virtual building can give us other rewards.

title: Lowe's Adding Fulfillment Centers, Large-Appliance Sites for Faster Delivery
summary: Bulk distribution centers, cross-dock terminals are part of a $1.7 billion supply-chain overhaul. Lowe's Cos. is beefing up its logistics network, with plans to add dozens of distribution and shipment-handling sites as part of a $1.7 billion overhaul aimed at speeding orders to customers of the home-improvement retail chain.

title: New Jersey Schools Can Reopen With All-Remote Learning After Governor's Reversal
summary: Districts, teachers unions pushed back on Gov. Murphy's original plan calling for some in-person instruction. New Jersey schools will be allowed to offer all-remote instruction in the fall, a reversal from the Murphy administration's earlier position that required in-person classes in some fashion, officials said.

title: Why the New Xbox Series X Might Lose Its Appeal to Gamers
summary: Thecoronavirus pandemic has delayed the release of the latest Halo game. Microsoft is releasing its new Xbox Series X console in November, but it will have to do so without an important launch partner: the latest "Halo" game. No console depends on a single game. But "Halo" has been one of the most popular franchises for the Xbox platform ever since Microsoft released its first console in 2001. The latest iteration, "Halo Infinite," was slated for release alongside the Xbox Series X, but the game's developer said it had been delayed until next year, partly because of Covid 19-related factors.

title: N.J. Supreme Court Clears Gov. Murphy's $10 Billion Borrowing Plan
summary: The state's top court said law is constitutional under an exemption for disasters. The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld a law giving the state the authority to borrow $9.9 billion to cover a budget shortfall stemming from the coronavirus shutdown.

title: Can't Escape the City? 'Anne of Green Gables' to the Rescue!
summary: If you're starved for country life this summer, teleport to Anne Shirley's fictional Prince Edward Island world, where the famed chatterbox and her relentless optimism is sure to sate your appetite. I WOULD HAVE thought by now that I could reread "Anne of Green Gables" without weeping. After all, aren't we a little too old and cynical for irrepressible child heroines, especially one who's relentlessly optimistic? Even Anne's creator, L.M. Montgomery, tended toward darker heroines in a later series, "Emily of New Moon," and the latest adaptation of "Green Gables," Netflix's "Anne with an E," surfaces the traumas glossed over in the original. But revisiting the 1908 childhood classic reminds me that a world steeped in beauty, kindred spirits and kindness is one we never stop longing for.

title: New York City Finds Coronavirus Case Rise in Brooklyn Neighborhood
summary: With citywide infection rate hovering around 1%, health officials say two weeks of testing found 6.9% infection rate in Sunset Park. New York City officials are pledging to test as many Sunset Park residents as possible for the new coronavirus after finding a significant increase in cases in the Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: Rising Treasury Yields Challenge Precious Metals Rally
summary: Traders anticipate more swings as bond yields head higher, sapping appetite for assets that don't offer income. Gold prices closed slightly higher after a wild trading session Wednesday, extending a volatile spell for the market as climbing yields on U.S. government bonds sap investors' appetite for the precious metal.

title: REI Wants to Sell Its Elaborate HQ Because of Covid-19
summary: Surprised by how productive remote work has been, companies are reconsidering the need for central offices. Recreational Equipment Inc. is looking to sell its custom-made new headquarters and allow employees to work from home or other offices, the latest sign that the pandemic is driving companies to ditch central offices to raise cash.

title: JFK Airport Tests Thermal Imaging to Screen for Signs of Covid-19
summary: In voluntary program, passengers with a reading above 100.4 degrees F can choose to give details of their flights, and boarding is at discretion of airlines. John F. Kennedy International Airport's busiest terminal is testing thermal imaging technology to screen passengers departing from New York City for signs of Covid-19.

title: 'Ted Lasso' Review: A Clueless Coach Confronts New Rules
summary: A comedy on AppleTV+ stars Jason Sudeikis as an American football coach who is hired to take charge of a struggling English soccer team, despite knowing nothing of the sport.. It takes no time at all to see that "Ted Lasso" is a gleefully ridiculous show based on a ludicrous premise: An American college football coach-one who doesn't know relegation from jubilation-is hired by a struggling English Premier League soccer team whose followers make New York Jets fans seem like chess-club cheerleaders. That the coach himself is a live-action knockoff of Ned Flanders certainly doesn't make it any less mad.

title: Cities Weigh Cutting Police Budgets and Discover How Hard That Is
summary: Resume Subscription. Cities across America are weighing whether to reduce or redirect spending on police. Some, with backing from mayors and city councils, are already undertaking efforts to do so, as protesters in their streets call for "defunding."

title: Renovation Rethink?
summary: Rather than proceeding with its planned refit of Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic should make the space a temporary lab in which to figure out what configuration best suits post-pandemic performance..

title: Off-Price Retailer Stein Mart Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Discount department-store chain, which sought chapter 11 protection in Florida, intends to close all or most of its 280 stores. Stein Mart Inc. has filed for bankruptcy with plans to permanently close all or most stores, becoming the latest distressed retailer to succumb to the economic fallout caused by restrictions due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Treasurys Stabilize After 10-Year Note Auction
summary: Yields had climbed as big debt auctions weigh on the market. U.S. government bonds came under selling pressure for the fourth straight session Wednesday though there were signs of stabilization following a $38 billion auction of new 10-year notes.

title: U.S. Deficit Totaled $2.8 Trillion From October Through July
summary: Budget gap more than tripled in first 10 months of fiscal year as government spending to combat the coronavirus outpaced federal tax collection. WASHINGTON-The federal deficit more than tripled in the first 10 months of the fiscal year, as government spending to combat the coronavirus continued to outpace federal tax collection, the Treasury Department said Wednesday.

title: These Books on Friendship Will Cure Quarantine Loneliness
summary: From 'Nobel-worthy' picture books to Patti Smith's 'Just Kids,' great stories about kindred spirits, according to director Alice Wu, Rachel Shukert of 'The Baby-sitters Club' and novelist Jasmin Darznik. "'My Friend is Sad' is the most brilliant instruction manual on how to be a good friend. Yes, it's also a picture book for 5-year-olds that will make you snort with laughter. For those reasons, Mo Willems deserves a Nobel. In Colum McCann's 'Let the Great World Spin,' each chapter sweeps a light across a new character-until almost imperceptibly, you come away from the whole feeling strangely less alone. That feels relevant-sheltered-in-place in our separate chapters, yet there is a larger book that binds us all together."

title: What to Watch: An SNL-Style Mystery Comedy With Bits From Maya Rudolph, Tina Fey and More
summary: Plus: Germany's favorite Netflix series, RZA's recent obsession and a way to scratch your summer blockbuster itch. Road-trip flicks are a genre of their own, and now comes a serial version from HBO, only this time with a twist. "Lovecraft Country" is a road trip fantasy thriller that follows Atticus Freeman (Jonathan Majors), who takes a road trip with his friend Letitia (Jurnee Smollett) and uncle George (Courtney B. Vance) to find his missing father. As they travel across segregated America of the 1950s they have to fight off both racists and monsters in a story that mixes history with horror. "Lovecraft Country" premieres Sunday on HBO and is also available on HBO Max.

title: July Consumer Prices Rise Amid Increased Demand for Range of Goods, Services
summary: The consumer-price index climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.6% in July, the Labor Department says. WASHINGTON-U.S. consumer prices rose in July on higher costs for a range of products and services, a sign of firming inflation as demand for goods rebounded following steep declines earlier in the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Why Health Experts Are Worried About Russia's Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: They are concerned the drug was developed by cutting regulatory corners. Russia has taken a big step toward releasing the world's first Covid-19 vaccine. It registered the new vaccine, named Sputnik V, with its Health Ministry this week. This is considered the most important step in Russia to verify the safety of a drug before releasing it for medical use, similar to getting approval from the Food and Drug Administration in the U.S.

title: Kamala Harris, Biden Differed on Trade, Medicare for All. Here's a Guide to Their Positions.
summary: During the primaries, the pair shared goals such as raising corporate taxes and expanding health insurance to more Americans. Joe Biden and his running mate, Kamala Harris, share goals such as raising corporate taxes and expanding health insurance to more Americans, but they disagreed during the 2020 Democratic primary campaign on how to approach policy areas including climate and trade.

title: U.S. Audit Watchdog Overhauls Inspection Plan to Assess Virus Impact
summary: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is extending its window for audit reviews to ensure it covers more of the coronavirus period. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is extending its window for inspections to assess the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on audit quality.

title: Oil Demand Faces Bigger Coronavirus Shock Than Previously Thought
summary: OPEC leaves its forecast for a record-breaking rebound in 2021 unchanged. The coronavirus pandemic will have an even bigger impact on the global economy and its demand for oil than previously expected, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said Wednesday.

title: Checks and Balances Erode as Trump Flexes Power of the Purse
summary: Presidents have siphoned power from Congress for decades, with this one especially aggressive in the fiscal sphere. Days before President Trump signed executive actions Saturday to defer payroll taxes and resume enhanced unemployment benefits, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) warned he was on the wrong side of the constitution: "The power of the purse begins in the House."

title: U.S. Corn Supply Grows on Record Crop Yield
summary: USDA projects corn production in 2020 to further expand thanks to good growing weather in the Midwest. The U.S. corn supply-already projected to near record levels-is continuing to grow thanks to supportive weather in the Midwest that has improved crop yields.

title: AI Helps Forecast Volcanic Eruptions
summary: Sensors on the ground, in the sky and in space yield data that could more accurately forecast volcanic activity around the world. Author

title: Mauritius Oil Spill Rescue Teams Scramble to Contain Damage
summary: Experts have said the environmental devastation could take years to repair. More than 1,000 metric tons of oil have seeped into the Indian Ocean from a cargo ship stranded off the coast of Mauritius, polluting coral reefs, lagoons and pristine shoreline. Now, rescue teams are racing to pump an estimated 3,000 metric tons from the Japanese-operated bulk carrier before it breaks up entirely.

title: Woody Johnson, U.S. Envoy to London, Made Insensitive Remarks, Watchdog Finds
summary: Ambassador, who owns New York Jets football team, also was effective advocate for U.S. policy, State Department inspector general finds. WASHINGTON-The U.S. ambassador to the United Kingdom made "inappropriate or insensitive comments" that threatened to create an offensive working environment and violate antidiscrimination laws, the State Department's internal watchdog found.

title: College Football Postponements Jeopardize Fox, ESPN Ad Bonanza
summary: Fox and ESPN have TV rights for Big Ten, Pac-12 football games, now postponed until next year. Walt Disney Co.'s ESPN and Fox Corp. stand to miss out on hundreds of hours of Saturday sports programming and big chunks of advertising revenue this fall if the bulk of college football's season doesn't happen until next year.

title: Punishment for the NRA Must Fit the Crime
summary: New York's attorney general knows it is impossible to protect donors by dissolving the organization that lobbies for their rights and interests.. New York Attorney General Letitia James says she has no choice but to seek the dissolution of the National Rifle Association to protect its members and donors from corrupt officials ("Gunning for the NRA," Review & Outlook, Aug. 7).

title: Comparing 'Cancel Culture' to McCarthyism
summary: We can only hope for another brave soul like Margaret Chase Smith, who stood up to the extreme element within her own party.. Lance Morrow's "Dawn of the Woke" (op-ed, Aug. 3) is as insightful as it is harrowing. The current climate of the "cancel culture" is indeed evocative of McCarthyism, but it is more frightful and destructive. Where the threshold for condemnation in the McCarthy era was alleged affiliation with "communist sympathizers," sufficient unto today is the mere failure to publicly join in the denunciation of the latest societal construct or historical figure to be branded as racist, fascist, sexist, homophobic, etc.

title: The Antitrust Case Against Big Tech Can't Pass Muster
summary: It is hard to see why Amazon shouldn't be permitted to negotiate its own shipping rates, and impossible to see how lower shipping costs hurt its customers.. Letters by Tom Wilson and Mark Noonan ("How Big Should Government Let Big Tech Be?" Aug. 6) in response to your editorial ("Big Tech's Antitrust Paradox," July 30) criticize alleged antitrust violations by the big technology firms. Mr. Wilson writes that once a company reaches near-monopoly status it is free to raise prices. This is conventional antitrust analysis, but it is meaningless in the context of services that are basically free, like Facebook , Google Search and YouTube. Apple can raise prices on its iPhones, but it is hardly a monopoly. It has competitors, like Samsung and Huawei, who would happily sell phones with similar features at a lesser price.

title: Electric Vehicles, Subsidies and the Public's Intelligence
summary: Washington has been distorting the automobile market for decades.. Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s "The Tesla Secret" (op-ed, Aug. 5) asks: "Why don't Wall Street and the press talk about how the [electric vehicle] business really works?" The answer is that in 2020 few people even remember the car industry from before regulations and tax laws reshaped it. President Obama's 54.5 miles per gallon corporate average fuel economy standard-reduced to 40 mpg by President Trump-and the credits the legacy manufacturers pay to Tesla are only the latest in a long line of regulations on and subsidies to the car and fuel businesses: the chicken tax, the intangible drilling cost preference and the percentage depletion rule come to mind, among many others.

title: Here's What You Need to Know About Kamala Harris, Joe Biden's Running Mate
summary: She is making history and has experience on the national stage, but has been criticized by some progressives. California Senator Kamala Harris, 55, is the first Black woman and first woman of Indian descent nominated for vice president by a major party. Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden vowed to select a woman as his vice president, and several Democrats pushed him to select a Black woman.

title: Taiwan Seeks to Start Free-Trade Talks With U.S.
summary: A pact would be part of island-democracy's effort to deepen its partnership with Washington and resist pressure from Beijing. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen said she wants to start talks on a free-trade pact with the U.S., part of a broad effort to deepen her island democracy's partnership with Washington and resist pressure from Beijing.

title: Hermitage Offshore Files for Bankruptcy Protection in U.S.
summary: Coronavirus pandemic shocks and oil-price pressure slammed offshore service business. Hermitage Offshore Services Ltd. filed for bankruptcy protection, its business of providing support for oil-drilling operations battered by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Oil Refiners Accelerate Shift to Renewables in Downturn
summary: Phillips 66 shift to biofuels at San Francisco-area oil refinery is industry's latest re-evaluation in light of Covid-19 and tightening environmental regulations. U.S. fuel makers see economic opportunity in getting greener as consumption remains depressed during the coronavirus pandemic and the prospect of more government regulations increases.

title: Model Train Enthusiasts Are Parking Their Railroads in Souped-Up Spaces
summary: Forget unfinished basements. These model railroaders are spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to build train rooms in their homes.. Retired professional golfer Ed Dougherty built a six-car garage for his home in Pennsylvania, but it contains no automobiles. None that are big enough to transport people, that is.

title: Yara Shahidi Is a New Kind of Young Hollywood Mogul
summary: The star of 'black-ish' and 'grown-ish' on her overall deal with ABC Studios, her role as a storyteller and her efforts to get young voters informed: "I'm working on honoring all of my desires". Ask Yara Shahidi how she self-identifies and she will reply that she is not an activist but "a creative and socially engaged human." The 20-year-old polymath has been in the entertainment industry since first appearing in TV commercials at the age of 6, and she made her big-screen debut alongside Eddie Murphy in the 2009 comedy Imagine That. Since then, starring roles on Kenya Barris's series black-ish and grown-ish-playing cool older sister Zoey Johnson-have placed her among the vanguard of young Hollywood. Shahidi has also been a brand ambassador for Chanel and Bobbi Brown Cosmetics and was featured in several ad campaigns for Coach. For her young fans, she's served as a voice on social justice in the arts and more. Her personal social media channels put her politics into practice: One day, she's leading a back-and-forth with her fans about the works of James Baldwin via Instagram, and the next, creating a TikTok urging teens to register to vote. She's also currently enrolled as a full-time student at Harvard University.

title: Kamala, Goddess of Wealth Creation
summary: It's 'comma-la,' and don't mix her up with the late pro wrestler.. Joe Biden has revealed the identity of his running mate: Sen. Kamala Devi Harris. Why did he take so long to decide? Maybe he needed time to learn how to say her name.

title: 'Covid Powers' Wreck My Neighborhood

summary: The growing fleet of idled vessels includes supertankers; together they hold millions of barrels of oil in an oversupplied energy market. title: Inflation Reading No Match for Fed's Dovish Turn
summary: Prices picked up in July, but investors are cueing off an expected shift in how the Federal Reserve responds to inflation. title: In 'Boys State,' Teens Play Politics and It Gets Messy

It is campaign politics in miniature, complete with mud-slinging, pandering and playing to the cheap seats.

title: In Luxury Goods, Pandemic Shows Bigger Is Better
summary: Big brands such as Louis Vuitton and Hermès have proved more resilient than smaller, independent Italian labels. The coronavirus crisis is widening the gap between the haves and the have-nots of the luxury goods industry.

title: Pompeo, EU Officials Warn Belarus Over Election, Protests

summary: Barclays and Goldman among bidders for auto maker's credit-card business, which has about $3 billion in outstanding balances. title: Airlines Are Withholding Billions in Refunds-That's Billions With a B
summary: Passengers with trips canceled months ago struggle to get refunds from some carriers or travel agencies, even with U.S. law on their side. Refunds delayed and denied. title: In Beirut, Hopes Fade of Finding Survivors From Explosion
summary: Rescue teams are racing against time as the political fallout from the government's resignation continues. title: When Will the Latest Coronavirus Unemployment Benefits Start? What We Know
summary: How much your check will be to how long the extra payment will last. President Trump signed an executive action on Aug. 8 for a federally funded $300 a week in enhanced unemployment benefits for workers laid off during the coronavirus pandemic. The payments would replace the $600 payments that expired last month. Mr. Trump called on states to provide another $100 a week, but administration officials said the state-funded benefit was optional.

title: How to Navigate Happy Hour in an Anxious Era
summary: Pondering a bottle of Junipero Gin, author (and extrovert) Jasmine Guillory rethinks social drinking as well as the history she learned in school. I AM AN extrovert, and I'm a social drinker. These are things I've always known about myself, but I've had to relearn both during this unending period of lockdown. Early on, worried, scared and uncertain, I drank a lot of wine with my elaborate solo dinners, but that just made everything worse-the wine would make me even more depressed, and drinking it by myself, alone in my apartment, felt sad. In early April, I decided to only drink in the situations where I used to drink: when I see friends and family, even though those visits are now either virtual or, if in person, from a distance. So the stout blue bottle of Junipero Gin sent to me by my editor at The Wall Street Journal was my companion on many virtual and some in-person socially distanced cocktail hours. It led to several illuminating conversations.

title: How a 30-Ton Robot Could Help Crops Withstand Climate Change

Within days, 71 people from the event tested positive for Covid-19.

title: Publishers Are Investing in a Second Generation of Audio Articles
summary: New York Times reporters get voice-over training; BBC invests in automated readers designed to sound like humans. Now they are developing humanlike reader technology and training reporters in the art of reading out loud to help people with overflowing "to-read" lists.

title: This European Digital Bank Is Prospering in the Pandemic
summary: Shares of an Italian internet bank which doesn't operate a traditional branch network are soaring, bucking a broader downward trend. The coronavirus pummeled shares of most banks as it ripped through economies world-wide in the first half of the year. But one European lender that specializes in investment advice and eschews a traditional branch network has flourished.

title: Companies Step Up Distribution Automation Under Pandemic Strains
summary: Robots are helping speed the flow of goods while workers maintain social distance in warehousing and fulfillment operations. summary: Chinese leader lays out new vision as Chinese companies are shut out of foreign markets. For decades, Chinese leaders embraced foreign investments and exports to power China's economy. title: To Keep Rallying, Gold Prices Need a New Fuel
summary: Tumbling real U.S. interest rates have fueled the sharp increase in the price of gold. To continue rallying toward lofty $3,000 forecasts, something more will be required.. title: European Soccer's Pandemic Experiment: A One-Off Champions League Tournament
summary: Eight of the best soccer clubs in Europe are gathering in Lisbon for in a single-elimination, made-for-television, 12-day spectacular. For all the novelty of empty stadiums, elbow bumps, and physically distanced locker rooms, European soccer's transition into its pandemic era was remarkably smooth. Once the hiatus was out of the way, domestic seasons finished up more or less as they would have in normal times. And even if the new precautions made the atmosphere of the most passionately followed sport on Earth quiet and weird, they didn't fundamentally alter the competition.

title: Who Is Kamala Harris? How Joe Biden's VP Pick Makes History
summary: The California senator is the first Black woman and first woman of Indian descent on a major party presidential ticket. Kamala Harris, the daughter of Jamaican and Indian immigrants, will make history on the Democratic presidential ticket.

title: Kodak Chief Says Company Supports Federal Decision to Halt Loan
summary: In a regulatory filing, Kodak flagged possible risks facing its initiative that could affect repaying the loan. title: Why Being Kind Helps You, Too-Especially Now
summary: Research links kindness to a wealth of physical and emotional benefits. And it's an excellent coping skill for the Covid-19 era.. In January, Rachel Glyn's husband of 36 years died of cancer. Two months later, the pandemic and lockdown hit. Alone in her Philadelphia apartment, Ms. Glyn spent her time worrying about the coronavirus, the financial markets and the civil unrest happening a few blocks away. Some days, she says, she wished she would die. "I'll never have another day that doesn't stink," she told herself.

title: After Chicago Looting and Coronavirus, Businesses Consider Closing Shop
summary: On Jeweler's Row, businesses saw their inventory wiped out. "Forty-two years of business-what I have is gone.". title: McDonald's Board Faces New Scrutiny of Investigation Into Ex-CEO
summary: Some shareholders question handling of Steve Easterbrook's departure, supervision of company. title: Watchdog Concludes Arms Sales to Gulf States Complied With U.S. Law
summary: Office of Inspector General said the $8 billion in weapons sales didn't include adequate measures to minimize civilian casualties. title: Moderna Inks $1.5 Billion Coronavirus Vaccine Deal With U.S.
summary: Under the U.S.'s latest deal for Covid-19 vaccines, Moderna agreed to supply 100 million doses. Moderna Inc. said Tuesday it agreed to provide the U.S. government 100 million doses of its experimental coronavirus vaccine in exchange for more than $1.5 billion.
